div.p: My time, it was difficult, it was difficult, dyslexia at that time, I’m 36 now, so 21 years ago dyslexia wasn’t recognised as much
as it is now and as it is now it’s a registered disability so I was very frustrated, I was very angry, I was one of the coolest kids
in the school so I thought I had to keep that sort of reputation so I never shared with my friends that I had dyslexia
or that I couldn’t read and write, I didn’t know what dyslexia was at the time, so it was that I couldn’t read and write because I wanted
to still be the cool boy of the school so when teachers asked me to do certain bits of work I would kick off and I always say now that
for me it was always the best form of defence is attack so I sort of attacked the teachers verbally and sometimes physically
so my schooling was very up and down, I never had any support from teachers because they didn’t know what dyslexia was
as much as they do now so in a nutshell I would say it was very frustrating and difficult. Being the man of the house because my dad was never on the scene
I sort of told my mum when I was going to go out and I told my mum when I was going to do homework and I told my mum when I was going to start doing this
and doing that and so I think my mum did encourage me but it sort of went in one ear and out the other.
